Posts.Content: So far so good, not had my anti sickness tablets yet only the one she gave me before chemo so a part from feeling really hungry I'm doing well. The steroids are so small dose from what I had with tax that I will cope better with them. Got a sore throat which came on a few hours after chemo so drinking loads and trying to eat softer foods. Got to have a central line put in next time as my veins are not good. How are you feeling now after your first tax?
Posts.Title: Not looking forward to starting FEC on Thursday

Posts.Content: Well done on your year and losing weight. I finished chemo last Thursday and got surgery in a month, I can't wait to have a drink to toast my end of chemo but I know I have to lose weight as put about a stone and half on putting it up to 5 stone I need to lose. I feel that is going to be my biggest battle losing the pounds but I know it is going to be for my health, so I'm going to enjoy my time up to Christmas and then once this is over I'm getting stuck in to the new healthier me. Enjoy your party and have fun x
Posts.Title: Raising a glass to everyone going through treatment

Posts.Content: Hi, I know I may not be of help as still going through treatment but having read what you've put it sounds like the post side effects as my Macmillan nurse calls it. I was told that it will take about a year to fully regain your energy if anyone can agree with that. I think once you've had your hysterectomy you will feel better as your having that for a reason. You've certainly been through the mill and being stressed is going to take every bit of energy but you need to talk to someone. If you go to your gp they should be able to refer you or put your in touch with your nearest MacMillan nurses who will understand what you are going through and offer advice. We think because the cancer is gone and there is no more treatment that we move on quickly but it is the stress and shock of what our bodies have gone through so if we don't feel poo afterwards then its amazing. I was told to expect having a bit of a breakdown as I approach my first year as the memories come back so I will be prepared for that as you go from having constant checks and talking to nothing. Hope that has been some help but I would definitely go and see your gp even if they refer you to 'mind' for mental health as its someone to talk to and they are great x
Posts.Title: nearly 10 months out if chemo and still feeling poo :(

Posts.Content: Thank you JuJuxx, getting a bit nervous but as soon as I get this one over with I'll know what I'm dealing with. I'll post on here tomorrow to let you know how it went x
Posts.Title: Not looking forward to starting FEC on Thursday

Posts.Content: With docetaxel, I found that wasn't that bad, its the heavy amount of steroids you have to take. On my first session I had a reaction so they gave me pirition before each one which made me very sleepy. The steroids made me extremely bloated and it made my IBS bad so I was allowed to take buscopan which stopped the pain so was bearable. I drank loads the first few days which helped with the bloating as the tax tends to retain fluids. I never got oral thrush, but did get sore throat, horrible feeling in my mouth where my tongue and the roof of my mouth felt rough and lost my taste buds. About day 5 I would get achy joints or back pain but I knew when it would start so I would start taking paracetamol every 4 hours to nip it in the bud so it wasn't so bad. Sleepless nights because of the steroids were bad but once you stop the steroids I was sleeping again. After a week I started feeling good again. Even though my hair started to fall out, it has stopped and what I have got has grown so if yours has started to grow you shouldn't really lose much. My oncologist said that most people find tax the hardest so I'm hoping that is true and fec will be easier but when you have got use to one, it is scary to end up with another and not knowing how you will react to it. Good luck, hopefully you will get through it OK x
Posts.Title: Not looking forward to starting FEC on Thursday

Posts.Content: Hi all, I'm starting FEC on Thursday after having 3 docetaxel but its the unknown which is starting to get to me. I learnt how to deal with the tax, what worked and what didn't but I've got to start all over again. Even though I lost a lot of hair but its still wispy and a fair covering but know that it will all come out now with the fear that my eye lashes/brows may go as well. The main thing is that I never had any nausea or sickness with tax, I hate being sick and really don't want to be so will live on the anti sickness drugs, I've had them before and didn't like them at all. I've heard so much about side effects that other people have had but everyone is different so just got to wait and see what mine will be. Hope everyone is doing OK x
Posts.Title: Not looking forward to starting FEC on Thursday

Posts.Content: With the steroids for tax, I had to take 4 in the morning and 4 in the evening day before, on the day and day after chemo, the 3 in the morning for the next 2 days, so if I have to take less of them for a few days I think I can handle that. I had to inject myself for 7 days but I had a reaction to those so they changed it to 1 slow release which I did they day after. I never felt sick so I never needed the sickness drugs and hoping that I won't be affected by it that much with this one, I will take the anti sickness drugs to be on the safe side. Like wise, anything you want to know, just ask x
Posts.Title: Not looking forward to starting FEC on Thursday

Posts.Content: Hi, what changes have you experienced since chemo? After my 1st chemo, I had rice for dinner one evening, within a couple of hours I was getting use to sitting on the throne as I was in and out of the loo and had bad stomach ache. Since then, I've tried twice now and each time I have a small portion of rice I get a bad stomach and can't be too far away from the bathroom. I have also found that if I eat late in the evening I get bad reflux and the other thing is alcohol. I didn't drink all the way through and now having finished chemo I fancy a drink now and again but each time I've had a drink I get reflux and insomnia, really thinking that its not worth it as I'm tired constantly and this really isn't helping. A friend of mine, her husband after chemo can't eat meat as he became very ill every time. Its strange just what chemo can do to our bodies and so far it looks like that I have to give up rice and become tea total but thankfully its not stopped me from eating cake lol x
Posts.Title: Food changes

Posts.Content: I've finished docetaxel and just had my 1st fec and I will say fec is easier. I got use to what worked and what didn't on tax and I knew that day 5 would be my worse but as long as I rested I would get through it. Basically for me I wouldn't sleep because of the high steroids you take and I suffer with IBS and the steroids and tax would upset that. I was given lansopazole and took buscopan which helped a lot. I did suffer with reflux and indigestion which a bottle of gaviscon went down well. My nails haven't fallen off but are very ridged so I keep them short and use hand cream. I never took any anti sickness drugs as never felt sick but I have put on weight as tax will make you retain fluid and steroids will make you eat. I had achy joints which would last a couple of days so I knew day 5/6 I need to take paracetamol/codine to stop it getting worse. Generally I felt like I had flu with sweating at night as well. I injected myself with the white cell injections but I had my changed to the 1 slow release as I had a reaction to the 1 a day and ended up in hospital for 3 days, they just don't know who will react. They will paint the absolute worse of things and hope you get it good, after my 1st cycle every one has been better but compared to fec tax is worse. All I can say is be prepared to feel s### for a week, the bloating, fluid retention, aches, tiredness, sickness whichever you get will go and resting will help alot. I expected to be really bad but I have an open mind to things and unfortunately I tend to look on the bright side and won't let things beat me so my experience won't help others as I paint a bright sunny picture when it seems pretty black lol Hope I've helped you in some way, I was the same about starting fec, its the unknown and I actually wanted to stay on tax as I got it under control but now I'm glad fec has worked out well for me. Good luck and let us know how you get on x
Posts.Title: Docetaxil experiences

Posts.Content: JuJuxx are you not given antibiotics automatically? On my 1st cycle they gave me a big bag full of meds, antibiotics to take on day 8 with antifungal, and its only because I was ill because of the white cell injections I now take them on day 5 and for longer as I'm a high risk of getting infection. If no one else gets these automatically then that might explain why I've handled this so well. I feel bad as I made it all sound so great and not as scary and you've had such a bad time of it on your first cycle of tax. Big hugs JuJuxx and hope you start to feel better x
Posts.Title: Docetaxil experiences

Posts.Content: Hi, yes had all of that, its the chemo and steroids that like to cause it. Throat, I tend to drink loads, have throat sweets, they do say chewing gum but I've not done that. I generally just learnt to cope with it as I know its only for a week and then everything settles and gets back to some form of normal. The shortness of breath is the steroids, and I've found really trying to relax does ease it but with the school holidays and 2 children that's hard to do. Achy joints, just take paracetamol every 4 hours, if thats not helping get it with codine. I suffer with bloating from the steroids and I get it really bad causing reflux and indigestion so I live off gaviscon. I know its hard when going through it but it does get easier and you will find what works. I've just learnt what is working for me and then the chemo is changing to fec next time so got to start all over again x
Posts.Title: docetaxel effects

Posts.Content: After my first chemo I did get pain in my left bust and underarm so assumed that the chemo was attacking the cancer as I still have my tumour and lymph nodes. Numbness - not had that, where are you getting it? Chemo can cause numbness in fingers and toes, speak to the cancer nurse about that x
Posts.Title: docetaxel effects

Posts.Content: I get this every time, its a side effect to the chemo. My glands always come up from about day 5 giving me a sore neck and after 2days they go down. I'm given antibiotics to start on day 5 as I'm a high risk of getting infections. My tongue goes pure white and have a really funny feel to it with complete loss of taste. Just some of the joys we have to endure whilst having chemo x
Posts.Title: docetaxel effects

Posts.Content: Hi, when I was on tax I couldn't eat bread as I found it felt like I was eating dough so I did eat a lot of soup with strong flavours as I lost my taste buds and pasta, I couldn't eat rice as that upset my stomach. Try milky products again as your taste may have changed, I found a big difference between tax and fec as I lived on milkshakes, hot chocolate as I couldn't drink coffee and ice cream or ice lollies on tax. I'm afraid it is trial and error, drink plenty of fluids as that will help with the sore mouth but I had to try different juices to add flavour and what made my mouth feel better. Mine lasted about a week before I got my mouth bad to feeling normal and getting some taste. Sorry I can't be too much help as everyone is different so hopefully someone else will give you more ideas, good luck x
Posts.Title: TAX - Sore Mouth - What to Eat?

Posts.Content: Hi, there's nothing better than knowing that the chemo is working. I had 3 tax and I'm about to have my 3rd fec, I saw my oncologist yesterday and she said that the tumour is basically gone and the thick tissue that surrounded it is shrinking so hopefully there won't be much left to be removed when I have my surgery in November. Tax will be hard going compared to fec but just keep in mind that it is doing what its suppose to do. Good luck, you will be fine, the main days are from 3/4 when you start to feel real rough but keep going, take paracetamol reguraly and rest x
Posts.Title: Start Tax Tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi, I've finished all my chemo I had 3 tax and 3 fec and to be perfectly honest I didn't let it stop me. Having 2 young children who needed taking to school/pick up, birthday parties and entertaining I had to get on with it. I started my treatment at the start of the 6 weeks holidays so they got use to the 1st week after chemo of not doing much. I might take them to the park and sit while they played, then my 2nd week we started to do more. Once they went back to school, I would do things when I felt like it, housework waited but I still went out with friends for coffee or lunch. Shopping I would do once I dropped the kids off or in the evening, it was quiet so nicer to walk round without too many people looking at me in my hat. Depending on how you feel, do what you can handle, if you stop doing what you feel like then you will feel bad. A part from the chemo side effects, I felt great and didn't feel ill for long, you soon get use to the cycle. Everyone is different, there are some who cannot get out of bed, there's some who go running everyday, just go with how your body feels, but you shouldn't let this stop things you just have to adjust x
Posts.Title: Chemo advise please ?

Posts.Content: Hi, when I went in to have my lump checked they asked if I had any lumps under my arms I said no. On examination they thought the lump was a cyst but it hurt when she pressed down under my arm. The ultrasound looked suspect so a biopsy was done and it came back that there were cancer cells in lump and lump nodes. I'm having a lumpectomy as my tumour has responded very well to chemo but she can't say how my lymph nodes they will have to remove until they go in, I know that 2 had cancer in but they might remove surrounding ones just to be on the safe side, I would prefer that so I know it can't spread anytime soon. Keep strong, its better they remove them than leave them, try and think of it as a positive than a negative, you are doing really well x
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer has spread to nodes, panicking

Posts.Content: Hi, welcome and you've come to the right place. I had a groshog line put in after having 4 rounds of chemo. Tax chemo absolutely kills the veins but after the 1st fec where they had problems putting a cannula in it was decided to put a line in. I couldn't have a picc line in as they couldn't find a vein so they said as groshog. I'm so glad I did have it and wish it was put in before my 1st session as it made my life so much easier. Everything is going to overwhelm you but take one thing at a time. I was having chemo first so I only read info on that, then I had surgery so read a few things on that a few days before. I'm having radiotherapy in the new year so I'll read up on that nearer the time, you can turn yourself in knots trying to make sense of it and if you are not sure of anything, here is a great place to ask. Hope that has been of some help to you x
Posts.Title: About to start chemo. Implantable port/central line?

Posts.Content: Hi, I finished my chemo on the 23rd of October and I'm having my surgery on Tuesday (25th November). I think it depends on how well you've responded to chemo and what your surgeon prefers x
Posts.Title: How long have you waited to have surgery after chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi, I had my 1st tax and my hair started coming out 12 days after. I showered that morning and my hair was covering my hands and all day I was pulling loads off my clothes, body etc and as it was hot and sweaty i couldn't stand it so the clippers came out and it was shaved off. I wear a scarf indoors and a hat when I go out, I've not bothered with a wig even though I had a wobble about going out and people looking at me. I'm about to have my 3rd tax tomorrow and I'm surprised by the amount of hair I still have but I'm sure it will all come out when I start on fec. I know it is a dignity thing but I still have my tumour and after just 2 cycles they couldn't really find it to measure it on monday so I know it has worked so I look at that being the positive and that keeps me going. I know how you feel, it is scary but it just for a few months and I am planning my new hair styles for when it start to grow back. Good luck with your treatment and with your decision with your hair x
Posts.Title: Hair loss :-(

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm having a groshong line put in on Wednesday and just wondered if anyone could answer some questions for me. How long does it take to put in? Will I be able to drive home from hospital afterwards or will I need someone to take me? I'm hoping I can drive home as I've not got someone who can take me. Thanks in advance x
Posts.Title: Groshong line

Posts.Content: Hi, I had pins and needles on my 1st tax and itchy palms and feet, this is a side effect. I had mine reduce for the next 2 tax and I never got it again. Ask for your next chemo to be reduced as this can lead to more problems but the oncologist should know that this is a possible side effect. Good luck x
Posts.Title: Pins and needles in fingers

Posts.Content: Hi, some people just react to them and I was one of them. Apparently its always day 5 when you start to feel unwell, I was taken in on day 7. I have now been changed to just the 1 injection instead of 1 a day for 7 days. When did you have your 1st chemo?
Posts.Title: infection risk

Posts.Content: My side effects are flu like, the day after chemo I had loads of energy but I would sit and rest as didn't want to over do it. No sickness or nausea so haven't taken the anti sickness drugs., I lost my taste so nothing tasted nice. The joint pain comes on about day 5 so I take paracetamol every 4 hours to prevent it getting worse, that seems to be my low days for about 2 days. The worse part is the steroids, I don't sleep for about a week and they interact with my ibs so my stomach gets bad and I spend some quality time with the loo! A part from that I know its only for a few days and once the steroids are finished I know I will sleep. I'm going to take buscopan this cycle as I suffered with my stomach and got the OK from my oncologist. Everyone is different so hopefully you won't be too bad, as I had the reaction from the injections first time, this last cycle was a breeze. My cycle of fec I'm sure will bring something new but just pleased not to have to have the steroids x
Posts.Title: infection risk

Posts.Content: Hi, I had an infection after my 1st chemo which was due to the white cell injections I was having. My symptoms were sweating, high temperature, pain all over my body. I phoned the hospital and was told to come in, I was put in isolation for 3 days as was at risk of further infection. Since then after my 2nd, I had a couple of days where I felt like I had flu but nothing compared to the first. What you have described sounds like side effects but if your temperature goes up then you need to contact them. Which chemo are you on?
Posts.Title: infection risk

Posts.Content: Yes, you will be fine with that, I was changed to that because of the reaction to the other one. I've got 1 more tax to go then I'm having 3 fec, how did you get on with that, what side effects did you get?
Posts.Title: infection risk

Posts.Content: Well done to have got through it. Its been tough going but I'm glad I had my last one today, got my surgery booked for 25th November so hopefully there won't be much to remove just wait to see how many lymph nodes will be removed. We are strong and if we got through chemo we can get through anything! X
Posts.Title: Last chemo done, 3 x FEC and 3 x Taxatere. Done! finito!!

Posts.Content: Hi, everyone handles things differently and cope with things in their own way. Your sister needs to have her down days and support from friends and family is the best way for her cope. Personally for me, I'm probably the minority but I've not let this get me down. I'm stage 2 and have just completed 6 cycles of chemo, surgery is in as couple of weeks and then I'll have radiotherapy after Christmas. I know the outcome is good, I've shown good progress etc all the way through but I'm happy, I've not cried at all and not been sad/upset, I'm not saying that I'm Supergirl but once this is over the reality of this may come crashing down, this is how I'm dealing with it now with a positive mind and attitude and 2 young children. The one thing I like is friends coming round or going out for coffee and the biggest cake going! As long as you are there for your sister and hopefully she will log on here and see that everything she needs to know and the support she gets here will help her through. If there is anything you want to know then just ask x
Posts.Title: breast cancer newbie

Posts.Content: Hi, I mirror what lesley58 said, don't look at other sites as you will get horror stories. I was given loads of booklets when I was diagnosed on chemo, operations etc but to be perfectly honest, I've only looked through a couple as I felt keeping reading things will do my head in, maybe that's why I've handled this well as I've just listened to my doctors and read things on here by people who have gone through this. Sometimes having too much info can completely make you feel worse, get in touch with the Macmillan nurses and talk to them, mine has been a breath of fresh air, so helpful and understanding. They will support you in anyway and answer questions that you may have, you have had bad news, giving up smoking etc all at the same time so you are quite rightly going to suffer with anxiety. Any more questions, just post on here and we will all help to answer x
Posts.Title: breast cancer newbie

Posts.Content: Hi, welcome to a place where we don't want to be but glad we have somewhere to go. This is the site to ask whatever questions you want answers to, we have people who are through all stages of treatment and can give advice on anything. Please feel free to ask away and we will try to help you x
Posts.Title: breast cancer newbie

Posts.Content: This is such an exciting day today, I never thought I would feel like this but this morning as I was putting my make up on I noticed on my lower eye lid that the eyelashes are growing back! I keep looking and feeling them and yes they are still there. As I've still had some sparce hair on my head not really been able to tell if its growing so where I lost my lower lid lashes, this is the first tell tale sign that everything is coming back
Posts.Title: An exciting day!

Posts.Content: Thank you all, on another inspection of my head area, I have found I now have hair up my nose! My eyebrows are still there but thinned out but on my right eyebrow I had as bit of a bald patch and can see some hair growing there as well. Just so exciting, keep touching my lashes and can't wait to put mascara on them soon x
Posts.Title: An exciting day!

Posts.Content: Hi, I had a lumpectomy 2 weeks ago and I've had nothing but pain shooting all over the place on my breast, I'm seeing the surgeon tomorrow so was going to ask about it. I'm assuming its because everything is readjusting to surgery but if anyone else can answer I would be more than interested but I don't think its anything to worry about x
Posts.Title: Boob pain after lumpectomy
